atomic_tests.name: Set a file's access timestamp
atomic_tests.description: Stomps on the access timestamp of a file

target_filename.description: Path of file that we are going to stomp on last access time

dependencies.description: The file must exist in order to be timestomped

atomic_tests.name: Set a file's modification timestamp
atomic_tests.description: Stomps on the modification timestamp of a file

target_filename.description: Path of file that we are going to stomp on last access time

dependencies.description: The file must exist in order to be timestomped

atomic_tests.name: Set a file's creation timestamp
atomic_tests.description:
Stomps on the create timestamp of a file

Setting the creation timestamp requires changing the system clock and reverting.
Sudo or root privileges are required to change date. Use with caution.

target_filename.description: Path of file that we are going to stomp on last access time

atomic_tests.name: Modify file timestamps using reference file
atomic_tests.description:
Modifies the `modify` and `access` timestamps using the timestamps of a specified reference file.

This technique was used by the threat actor Rocke during the compromise of Linux web servers.

target_file_path.description: Path of file to modify timestamps of

reference_file_path.description: Path of reference file to read timestamps from

atomic_tests.name: Windows - Modify file creation timestamp with PowerShell
atomic_tests.description:
Modifies the file creation timestamp of a specified file. This technique was seen in use by the Stitch RAT.
To verify execution, use File Explorer to view the Properties of the file and observe that the Created time is the year 1970.

target_date_time.description: Date/time to replace original timestamps with

file_path.description: Path of file to change creation timestamp

dependencies.description: A file must exist at the path (#{file_path}) to change the creation time on

atomic_tests.name: Windows - Modify file last modified timestamp with PowerShell
atomic_tests.description:
Modifies the file last modified timestamp of a specified file. This technique was seen in use by the Stitch RAT.
To verify execution, use File Explorer to view the Properties of the file and observe that the Modified time is the year 1970.

target_date_time.description: Date/time to replace original timestamps with

file_path.description: Path of file to change modified timestamp

dependencies.description: A file must exist at the path (#{file_path}) to change the modified time on

atomic_tests.name: Windows - Modify file last access timestamp with PowerShell
atomic_tests.description:
Modifies the last access timestamp of a specified file. This technique was seen in use by the Stitch RAT.
To verify execution, use File Explorer to view the Properties of the file and observe that the Accessed time is the year 1970.

target_date_time.description: Date/time to replace original timestamps with

file_path.description: Path of file to change last access timestamp

dependencies.description: A file must exist at the path ("#{file_path}") to change the last access time on

atomic_tests.name: Windows - Timestomp a File
atomic_tests.description:
Timestomp kxwn.lock.

Successful execution will include the placement of kxwn.lock in #{file_path} and execution of timestomp.ps1 to modify the time of the .lock file. 

[Mitre ATT&CK Evals](https://github.com/mitre-attack/attack-arsenal/blob/master/adversary_emulation/APT29/CALDERA_DIY/evals/data/abilities/defensive-evasion/4a2ad84e-a93a-4b2e-b1f0-c354d6a41278.yml)

atomic_tests.name: MacOS - Timestomp Date Modified
atomic_tests.description: Stomps on the modification timestamp of a file using MacOS's SetFile utility

target_filename.description: Path of file that we are going to stomp on last modified time

target_date.description: Date to replace original timestamps with

dependencies.description: The file must exist in order to be timestomped
dependencies.get_prereq_command: echo 'T1070.006 MacOS file modified timestomp test' > #{target_filename}

atomic_tests.name: Event Log Manipulations- Time slipping via Powershell
atomic_tests.description:
Changes the system time on the computer to a time that you specify. It involves altering the systemâ€™s clock or adjusting the dates of files, affecting timestamp integrity within Event Logs. This technique can disrupt the sequence of logged events, complicating incident analysis and forensics. 
Reference - 
https://detect.fyi/event-log-manipulations-1-time-slipping-55bf95631c40
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.utility/set-date?view=powershell-7.4

days_to_modify.description: Value to which system time will update
